{{Infobox storm |name=October 2015 North American storm complex |image location=October 3, 2015 US East Coast nor'easter.jpg |image name=Satellite image of the storm over the Eastern United States on October 3, with [[Hurricane Joaquin]] to the southeast. |stormtype=[[Extratropical cyclone]]; [[nor'easter]] |date formed=September 29, 2015 |date dissipated=October 7, 2015 |maximum rain={{convert|26.88|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Mount Pleasant, South Carolina|Mount Pleasant]], [[South Carolina]]<ref name="WPC13">{{cite report|author=Jason Krekeler |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |date=October 5, 2015 |accessdate=October 6, 2015 |title=Storm Summary Number 13 for Southeast U.S. Heavy Rain and Coastal Storm |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc2.html |archivedate=October 6, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6c5JZMcYR?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc2.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |pressure=998 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[Pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 29.47 [[Inches of Mercury|inHg]])<ref name="WPC4"/> |total damages (USD)=$2 billion (2015 [[United States dollar|USD]])<ref name="billions" /> |total fatalities=At least 25 deaths |areas affected=[[Eastern United States]] <small>(especially [[South Carolina]])</small>, [[Atlantic Canada]] }} The '''October 2015 North American storm complex''' was an [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical storm]] that triggered a high precipitation event, which caused historic [[flash flood]]ing across [[North Carolina|North]] and [[South Carolina]]. The incipient [[cold front]] traversed the [[Eastern United States]] on September 29–30, producing heavy rain in multiple states. The system subsequently stalled just offshore. Tapping into moisture from the nearby [[Hurricane Joaquin]], a developing [[Low-pressure area|surface low]] brought heavy, continuous rain to southeastern States, with the worst effects concentrated in South Carolina where catastrophic flooding occurred. The event culminated in South Carolina on October 4 when numerous rivers burst their banks, washing away roads, bridges, vehicles, and homes. Hundreds of people required rescue and the state's emergency management department urged everyone in the state not to travel.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Ben Brumfield, Nick Valencia |author2=Greg Botelho |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Flash flood emergencies spread in South Carolina; motorists stranded in water|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/04/us/east-coast-rain-flood/}}</ref> Some areas of the state saw rainfall equivalent to a [[return period|1-in-1000-year event]].
At least 25 deaths have been attributed to the weather complex: 19 in South Carolina, 2 in [[New York (state)|New York]], 2 in North Carolina, 1 in [[Florida]], and 1 in [[New Brunswick]]. Damage from the storm reached $2 billion dollars.<ref name="billions">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/billions/events|title=Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters: Table of Events|author=|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|date=2015|accessdate=September 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Meteorological synopsis== [[File:October 2015 South Carolina flood infrared satellite animation.webm|thumb|left|Infrared satellite animation from October 1–5 depicting the evolution of the rainfall event over South Carolina.]] On September 29, 2015, a [[cold front]] moved southeast across the [[Eastern United States]] and produced widespread heavy rain.<ref name="Sep2930WPC">{{cite report|author=Jason Krekeler |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |date=September 30, 2015 |accessdate=October 3, 2015 |title=Storm Summary Number 4 for Eastern U.S. Heavy Rainfall Event |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc1.html |archivedate=October 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6c0BIpXvQ?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/discussions/nfdscc1.html |location=College Park, Maryland |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> By October 2, the frontal system stalled offshore and a 1000 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[Pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 29.53 [[Inches of Mercury|inHg]]) surface low developed just east of the [[Florida]]–[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] border. The cyclone interacted with [[Hurricane Joaquin]]—situated over [[the Bahamas]] at the time—with moisture streaming north from the hurricane into the [[Southeastern United States]].<ref name="WPC1">{{cite report|author=Michael Ryan |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |date=October 2, 2015 |accessdate=October 3, 2015 |title=Storm Summary Number 01 for Eastern U.S. Mountain and Coastal Storm |location=College Park, Maryland |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_1.html |archivedate=October 3, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6c0BN2yzu?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_1.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> This moisture interacted with the surface low, frontal boundary, and a strong [[cold-core low|upper-level low]] to produce prolonged, heavy rains over the region with [[Training (meteorology)|training bands]] situated over [[South Carolina]].<ref name="WPC4">{{cite report|author=Allison Santorelli |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |date=October 3, 2015 |accessdate=October 3, 2015 |title=Storm Summary Number 04 for Southeast U.S. Heavy Rain and Coastal Storm |location=College Park, Maryland |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_4.html |archivedate=October 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6c16NhDz3?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_4.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A strengthening [[Ridge (meteorology)|ridge]] to the northeast created a tighter [[pressure gradient]], resulting in a large area of onshore [[gale]]s.<ref name="WPC1"/>
==Preparations== [[File:South Carolina National Guard Prepares for Hurricane Joaquin.jpg|thumb|left|The [[South Carolina National Guard]] loading up sandbags for distribution across the state on October 3]] On September 30, [[Governor of Virginia|Virginia Governor]] [[Terry McAuliffe]] declared a [[state of emergency]] for the entire state owing to heavy rains and the threat of Hurricane Joaquin.<ref>{{cite web|author=Darcy Spencer|work=[[WRC-TV]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Hurricane Joaquin: Virginia Declares State of Emergency|url=http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Watching-Joaquin-Hurricane-Could-Threaten-East-Coast-330103561.html}}</ref> The [[Norfolk, Virginia|City of Norfolk]] also declared an emergency.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[WVEC]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc.]]|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Joaquin has been upgraded to a major category 3 hurricane. |url=http://www.13newsnow.com/story/weather/2015/09/29/tropical-storm-joaquin-forms-off-east-coast/73019316/|location=Norfolk, Virginia}}</ref> On October 1, Governors [[Larry Hogan]], [[Chris Christie]], [[Pat McCrory]], and [[Nikki Haley]] declared a state of emergency for Maryland, New Jersey, North Carolina, and South Carolina respectively.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[WPVI-TV]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|title=Christie Declares State of Emergency in New Jersey Ahead of Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://6abc.com/weather/christie-declares-state-of-emergency-in-nj-ahead-of-joaquin/1011405/|location=Trenton, New Jersey}} *{{cite news|work=[[WMAR-TV]]|publisher=[[American Broadcasting Company]]|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|title=Md. declares state of emergency in 'abundance of caution' ahead of Hurricane Joaquin|url=http://www.abc2news.com/news/breaking-news/gov-hogan-to-declare-state-of-emergency-for-maryland}} *{{cite news|author1=Joe Marusak |author2=Cleve R. Wooston Jr. |author3=David Perlmutt |last-author-amp=yes |newspaper=Charlotte Observer|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|title= McCrory declares state of emergency for N.C. as Joaquin continues to intensify|url=http://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/local/article37171893.html}} *{{cite news|work=[[WHNS]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 1, 2015|title=Gov. Haley declares state of emergency for South Carolina|url=http://www.foxcarolina.com/story/30167075/gov-haley-declares-state-of-emergency-for-south-carolina|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref>
By October 3, approximately 22 million people were under [[flood warning]]s or [[flood watch|watches]]. The storm prompted the cancellation of 145 flights nationwide.<ref name="NBC1"/>
==Impact==
===Southeastern states=== One person was killed in North Carolina on October 1 when a tree fell on her car. Flooding in [[Brunswick County, North Carolina]] prompted the evacuation of 400–500 people. More than 10,000 people were without power in the state.<ref name="NBC1">{{cite news|author1=Jason Cumming |author2=Elizabeth Chuck |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Flash Floods, 'Once in 200 Years Rainfall Event' Loom in South Carolina|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/weather/flash-floods-once-200-years-rainfall-event-loom-south-carolina-n438041}}</ref> A second death was confirmed on October 5.<ref name="CNN2">{{cite news|author1=Michael Pearson |author2=Holly Yan |author3=Joe Sutton |last-author-amp=yes |work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=South Carolina flooding: 'We have lost everything'|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/05/us/south-carolina-east-coast-rain-flood/}}</ref> [[File:Cheraw Pee Dee pole flood level.jpg|thumb|A pole at a park in [[Cheraw, South Carolina]]. The ring around the pole indicates the height of the [[Pee Dee River]] during the 2015 flood.]] On October 4, a 9-year-old drowned after being pulled out to sea by [[rip current]]s near [[St. Pete Beach]], Florida.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lauren Rozyla|work=[[WFTS-TV]]|publisher=[[E. W. Scripps Company]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=St. Pete mother dealing with likely drowning death of young son at beach|url=http://www.abcactionnews.com/news/st-pete-mother-dealing-with-likely-drowning-death-of-young-son-at-beach}}</ref>
====South Carolina==== [[File:October 1–4, 2015, Carolinas rainfall.png|thumb|Rainfall accumulations across [[the Carolinas]] and surrounding states from October 1–4, ending at 6:24 p.m. EDT (22:24 UTC). Areas in white indicate accumulations in excess of {{convert|20|in|mm|abbr=on}}.]] Rainfall across parts of South Carolina reached [[return period|500-year event]] levels,<ref name="NBC2">{{cite news|author1=F. Brinley Bruton |author2=Gabe Gutierrez |author3=Elisha Fieldstadt |last-author-amp=yes |work=[[NBC News]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=East Coast Flooding: 'Once in 500 Years' Downpour Threatens South Carolina|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/weather/east-coast-flooding-once-200-years-downpour-threatens-south-carolina-n438216}}</ref> with areas near [[Columbia, South Carolina|Columbia]] experiencing a 1-in-1000 year event.<ref>{{cite tweet|author=[[The Weather Network|Chris Scott]]|user=ChrisScottWx|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Once in 1000 years rainfall event unfolding now in South Carolina. Columbia thru Sumter has seen 12–20" #SCFlood|number=650703641586892800}}</ref> Accumulations reached {{convert|24.23|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Boone Hall]] by 11:00 a.m. EDT (15:00 UTC) on October 4.<ref name="WPC8">{{cite report|author=Allison Santorelli |publisher=Weather Prediction Center |date=October 4, 2015 |accessdate=October 4, 2015 |title=Storm Summary Number 08 for Southeast U.S. Heavy Rain and Coastal Storm |location=College Park, Maryland |url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_8.html |archivedate=October 4, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6c21Bmk68?url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/winter_storm_summaries/storm15/stormsum_8.html |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> [[Charleston International Airport]] saw a record 24-hour rainfall of {{convert|11.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} on October 3. Nearly 30,000 people were without power in the state.<ref name="NBC2"/> One woman drowned in [[Spartanburg, South Carolina|Spartanburg]] on October 1 after her car was overwhelmed by flooding in an underpass.<ref>{{cite news|author=Dal Kalsi|work=[[WHNS]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Coroner: Woman killed when flood waters submerge her vehicle in Spartanburg|url=http://www.foxcarolina.com/story/30159537/coroner-called-to-incident-on-new-cut-road|location=Spartanburg, South Carolina}}</ref> On October 2, a plane crashed along the South Carolina side of [[Lake Hartwell]], killing all four occupants. The cause is currently unknown though there was light rain at the time of the incident.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Kayla Crandall|author2=Eric Dutkiewicz|lastauthoramp=yes|work=[[WPTA]]|publisher=[[Granite Broadcasting]]|date=October 2, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=4 dead in S.C. plane crash; aircraft registered to Warsaw councilman|url=http://www.21alive.com/news/local/Warsaw-registered-plane-crashes-in-South-Carolina-killing-four--330487151.html|location=Oconee County, South Carolina|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003022436/http://www.21alive.com/news/local/Warsaw-registered-plane-crashes-in-South-Carolina-killing-four--330487151.html|archivedate=October 3, 2015|df=}}</ref> On October 3, the [[Charleston Historic District]] was brought to a virtual standstill with most roads closed because of flooding.<ref>{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|website=[[WTVD]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Flooding Shuts Down Charleston's Historic District|url=http://abc11.com/weather/flooding-shuts-down-charlestons-historic-district/1014961/|location=Charleston, South Carolina}}</ref> Three deaths were confirmed in the state on October 2 and 3. Through the evening of October 3, [[South Carolina Highway Patrol|highway patrol]] reported 500 traffic accidents and 104 flooded roads.<ref name="TheState1">{{cite news|newspaper=The State|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title= SC emergency operations increased to OPCON 1 |url=http://www.thestate.com/news/local/article37451427.html}}</ref>
Early on October 4, the [[National Weather Service]] issued [[flash flood emergency|flash flood emergencies]] for [[Berkeley County, South Carolina|Berkeley]], [[Charleston County, South Carolina|Charleston]], and [[Dorchester County, South Carolina|Dorchester]] counties.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[WCSC-TV]]|publisher=[[Raycom Media]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Flash flood emergency declared for Tri-County area|url=http://www.live5news.com/story/30180429/flash-flood-emergency-declared-for-tri-county-area|location=Charleston, South Carolina}}</ref> From 4:00–7:30 a.m. EDT (08:00–11:30 UTC), [[Gills Creek]] in Columbia rapidly rose to {{convert|17.08|ft|m|abbr=on}} before the river gauge stopped reporting; this shattered the previous record crest of {{convert|9.43|ft|m|abbr=on}} in July 1997.<ref name="Accuweather">{{cite web|author=Heather Janssen|publisher=[[Accuweather]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Record-Breaking Rain Delivers Devastating Flooding to Parts of South Carolina|url=http://www.accuweather.com/en/weather-news/live-rain-lashes-eastern-us-ma/52740263}}</ref> The state's Emergency Management Division issued a statement later that morning via [[Twitter]] at 6:59 a.m. EDT, stating: "... remain where you are if you are safely able to do so."<ref>{{cite tweet|author=South Carolina Emergency Management Division|user=SCEMD|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=EMERGENCY ALERT: SCEMD asks you to remain where you are if you are safely able to do so. Call 911 for life-threatening emergencies #alert|number=650626218870616064}}</ref> They reiterated this at 8:20 a.m., stressing that residents should not travel: "Remain. Where. You. Are. Dangerous flooding conditions through the state for most of the day."<ref>{{cite tweet|author=South Carolina Emergency Management Division|user=SCEMD|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Remain. Where. You. Are. Dangerous flooding conditions through the state for most of the day. #SCFlood #SCtweets|number=650646771228504065}}</ref> The State's Emergency Management division also issued a statement not to move or drive around barricades blocking flooded roads, yet drivers still moved and/or drove around barricades. Three subjects died after someone else removed a barricade from a road; in the darkness, the three were unable to see that the road had been washed out, and they drove into a chasm.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wltx.com/news/local/flood-recovery/the-1000-year-flood-two-years-later_/480642802|title=The 1,000 Year Flood: Two Years Later|work=[[WLTX]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc]]|date=October 4, 2017|accessdate=October 4, 2017|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref> A dam along Semmes Lake at [[Fort Jackson (South Carolina)|Fort Jackson]] collapsed.<ref name="NBC2"/> More than 140 rescues were made during the overnight hours; the [[United States Coast Guard]] was deployed to assist in rescue missions.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[KTSA]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Coast Guard Joins Flood Rescue Efforts in South Carolina|url=http://www.ktsa.com/coast-guard-joins-flood-rescue-efforts-in-south-carolina/|location=Charleston, South Carolina|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005125252/http://www.ktsa.com/coast-guard-joins-flood-rescue-efforts-in-south-carolina/|archivedate=October 5, 2015|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Columbia, South Carolina, October 5, 2015, levee breach.jpg|thumb|left|A levee breach near Columbia, South Carolina, on October 5]] At 10:54 a.m. EDT (14:54 UTC) on October 4, 211 state roads and 43 bridges were closed.<ref name="Accuweather"/> On the same day, [[Georgetown County, South Carolina|Georgetown County]] Emergency Management closed all roadways in the county because of severe flooding; the South Carolina Emergency Management Division announced the closure of [[Interstate 95]] between [[Interstate 20]] and [[Interstate 26]], a {{convert|70|mi|km|abbr=on}} stretch.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wbtw.com/2015/10/02/flooding-closes-multiple-roads-in-horry-county/ |title=Extreme flooding causes road closures, evacuations |author=Jo brown |work=[[WBTW]] |date=October 4, 2015 |accessdate=October 4, 2015}}</ref> A mandatory curfew was put in place for Columbia beginning at 6:00 p.m. EDT (22:00 UTC).<ref>{{cite news|author=Jeremy Turnage|work=[[WIS]]|publisher=[[Raycom Media]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Mandatory curfew imposed for City of Columbia|url=http://www.wistv.com/story/30182220/mandatory-curfew-imposed-for-city-of-columbia}}</ref> All residents in the city were also advised to boil water as water lines suffered damage.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jeremy Turnage|work=[[WIS]]|publisher=[[Raycom Media]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=System-wide boil water advisory issued for all City of Columbia water customers|url=http://www.wistv.com/story/30182074/system-wide-boil-water-advisory-issued-for-all-city-of-columbia-water-customers}}</ref> One person died in the city after her car was swept away.<ref>{{cite news|author=Clif Leblanc|newspaper=The State|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 4, 2015|title=Flood death: Woman dies when SUV washes off Columbia street |url=http://www.thestate.com/news/local/article37726638.html}}</ref> Multiple school districts and colleges across the state were closed the week of October 5th, including [[Horry County Schools]], Georgetown County Schools, Williamsburg County Schools, Sumter County Schools, Charleston County Schools, [[University of South Carolina]], [[Coastal Carolina University]] and [[College of Charleston]].
Eighteen dams were breached or collapsed across the state.<ref>{{cite news|last=Chappell|first=Bill|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=18 Dams Breached And Death Toll Rises In S.C. Flooding|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/10/06/446352304/s-c-flooding-18-dams-breached-and-death-toll-rises}}</ref> A mandatory evacuation was issued for areas downstream of the [[Overcreek Dam]] on October 5 after the structure was breached.<ref name="CNN2"/> The head of the South Carolina National Guard compared damage from the floods to [[Hurricane Hugo]] in 1989, which caused $9.5 billion in economic losses. [[Reinsurance]] company [[Aon (company)|Aon Benfield]] indicated losses from the floods would be well in excess of $1 billion, with a large portion coming from uninsured homeowners.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ben Berkowitz|work=[[CNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=South Carolina flood losses: $1 billion and rising|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/10/06/south-carolina-flood-losses-1-billion-and-rising.html}}</ref>
At least 19 deaths were confirmed in relation to the storm, by the evening of October 9, 2015.<ref name="RecoveryCenters">{{cite news|work=[[WLTX]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc.]]|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 10, 2015|title=5 Recovery Centers Open, 19 Dead After Floods|url=http://www.wltx.com/story/news/local/2015/10/09/5-rcovery-centers-open-19-dead-after-floods/73695664/|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref>
The fallout from the flooding forced the [[South Carolina Gamecocks football|South Carolina Gamecocks]] to move their October 10 home game against the [[LSU Tigers football|LSU Tigers]] to [[Tiger Stadium (LSU)|Tiger Stadium]] in Baton Rouge. While [[Williams-Brice Stadium]] in Columbia was not heavily damaged, school officials felt the damage to the area's infrastructure was too severe to host the game.<ref name="FootballGame">{{cite news|last=Patterson|first=Chip|work=[[CBS Sports]]|date=October 7, 2015|accessdate=December 10, 2015|title=Flood moves LSU-South Carolina game from Columbia to Baton Rouge|url=http://www.cbssports.com/collegefootball/eye-on-college-football/25330316/south-carolina-lsu-moved-from-columbia-to-death-valley}}</ref>
===Northeastern states=== [[File:2015 Ocean City flooding2.jpg|thumb|right|Minor street flooding in [[Ocean City, New Jersey]]]] In Virginia, heavy rains resulted in numerous traffic accidents; state police responded to 375 incidents on October 3. Police received more than 1,200 calls that day. Power outages affected 7,300 customers at the height of the storm.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=Update: 4,600 without power in Virginia|url=http://www.richmond.com/weather/article_94651a44-692a-11e5-b98c-e7e48de48832.html}}</ref> The [[James River]] approached flood levels, and hundreds evacuated low-lying areas in [[Lancaster County, Virginia|Lancaster County]] on Virginia's [[Northern Neck]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Bill McKelway|newspaper=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title= Hundreds evacuate in Lancaster County; no injuries reported |url=http://www.richmond.com/weather/article_ed833434-bea0-5113-88d7-4032cf2dd037.html}}</ref>
Tidal flooding in [[Ocean City, Maryland]] prompted road closures.<ref name="NBC2"/> Rainfall in the state peaked at {{convert|4.67|in|mm|abbr=on}} near [[Bishopville, Maryland|Bishopville]].<ref name="WPC8"/> In [[Delaware]], the storm caused coastal flooding, with [[Delaware Route 1]] between [[Bethany Beach, Delaware|Bethany Beach]] and [[Dewey Beach, Delaware|Dewey Beach]] closed on October 2 due to flooding and not reopened until October 4.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flood|first1=Chris|last2=Lauria|first2=Maddy|title=Route 1 from Bethany to Dewey Beach reopens|work=Cape Gazette|date=October 3, 2015|url=http://www.capegazette.com/node/91260|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref>
Several days of continuous onshore flow caused significant coastal flooding and [[beach erosion]] in New Jersey.<ref name="WPVI-TV1"/> The worst erosion took place in [[Ocean County, New Jersey|Ocean County]], specifically around [[Mantoloking, New Jersey|Mantoloking]], where {{convert|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} of sand was washed away; [[Ortley Beach, New Jersey|Ortley Beach]] saw up to {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="NJ1">{{cite news|author=Alex Napoliello|work=[[NJ.com]]|publisher=[[Advance Digital]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=Nor'easter eroded N.J.'s beaches, but major property destruction averted|url=http://www.nj.com/ocean/index.ssf/2015/10/jersey_shore_beaches_hit_hard_by_storm_rebuild_aft.html}}</ref> Wind gusts up to {{convert|62|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}—the highest observed winds in relation to the [[nor'easter]]—were measured at [[Cape May, New Jersey|Cape May]].<ref name="WPC8"/> Coastal flooding in New Jersey destroyed at least one home.<ref name="NBC1"/> [[Stone Harbor, New Jersey|Stone Harbor]] sustained millions of dollars in damage to the beach.<ref name="WPVI-TV1">{{cite news|author=Annie McCormick|work=[[WPVI-TV]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=October 4, 2015|accessdate=October 5, 2015|title=Storm Brings Beach Erosion, Flooding at Jersey Shore|url=http://6abc.com/weather/ocean-city-nj-streets-flood-as-storm-strikes/1013388/}}</ref> At least 3,600 residences lost power in the state.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[WABC-TV]]|publisher=[[The Walt Disney Company]]|date=October 3, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Storm Continues to Soak New Jersey, Sends House Into Water|url=http://abc7ny.com/weather/storm-continues-to-soak-new-jersey-sends-house-into-water/1014657/|location=Sea Bright, New Jersey}}</ref> Despite severe coastal erosion, structural damage was limited.<ref name="NJ1"/>
On October 2, a fishing boat with five crew capsized amid {{convert|10|to|15|ft|m|abbr=on}} swells in [[Jamaica Bay]], near [[Floyd Bennett Field]] along the south coast of [[Long Island]], New York. Two people were able to swim to shore and signal rescue for the other three; two later died in the hospital.<ref>{{cite news|author=Brynn Gingras|work=[[WNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal]]|date=October 2, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=2 Men Dead After Fishing Boat Capsizes in Jamaica Bay: NYPD|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local/Fishermen-Die-Capsized-Boat-Jamaica-Bay-Storm-Fishing-NYC-Queens-330511561.html}}</ref>
Flooding in [[Portland, Maine]] stranded several vehicles.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[WCSH]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc.]]|date=September 30, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=Cars submerged in water behind Marginal Way in Portland|url=http://www.wcsh6.com/story/news/local/portland/2015/09/30/cars-water-marginal-way/73112324/|location=Portland, Maine}}</ref>
===Atlantic Canada=== Heavy rains associated with the incipient frontal boundary extended into [[Atlantic Canada]], with {{convert|160|mm|in|abbr=on|disp=flip}} of rain observed in parts of [[New Brunswick]]. Widespread flooding washed out roads and bridges, impairing travel; [[Hoyt, New Brunswick|Hoyt]] was rendered inaccessible. One person died in [[Berwick, New Brunswick|Berwick]] after a retaining wall collapsed on him.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[CTV News]]|publisher=[[Bell Media]]|date=October 1, 2015|accessdate=October 3, 2015|title=Intense storm in Maritimes blamed for death of N.B. man|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/canada/intense-storm-in-maritimes-blamed-for-death-of-n-b-man-1.2589751}}</ref>
==Aftermath== President [[Barack Obama]] declared parts of South Carolina a disaster area, making federal aid available in [[Charleston County, South Carolina|Charleston]], [[Berkeley County, South Carolina|Berkeley]], [[Dorchester County, South Carolina|Dorchester]], [[Georgetown County, South Carolina|Georgetown]], [[Horry County, South Carolina|Horry]], [[Lexington County, South Carolina|Lexington]], [[Orangeburg County, South Carolina|Orangeburg]], [[Richland County, South Carolina|Richland]], and [[Williamsburg County, South Carolina|Williamsburg Counties]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.journalnow.com/news/state_region/fire-hose-of-moisture-slams-south-carolina-killed/article_7cfe2a5c-8422-5f1e-b5b5-2c216982bfe2.html|title='Fire hose' of moisture slams South Carolina; 12 killed|agency=Associated Press|work=[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|date=October 5, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref> [[Calhoun County, South Carolina|Calhoun]], [[Clarendon County, South Carolina|Clarendon]], [[Kershaw County, South Carolina|Kershaw]], [[Lee County, South Carolina|Lee]], and [[Sumter County, South Carolina|Sumter]] counties were later added to the list of federal disaster areas.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wltx.com/story/weather/2015/10/04/historic-flooding-south-carolina/73236892/|title=THE LATEST: What You Need to Know About the Disaster|work=[[WLTX]]|publisher=[[Tegna, Inc]]|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=October 9, 2015|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref> More than 1,300 National Guard soldiers and 250 state troopers were mobilized across the state.<ref name="CNN2"/> The [[United States Department of Transportation]] released $5 million in emergency funds to the [[South Carolina Department of Transportation]] on October 6.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Amanda Shaw |author2=Dal Kalsi |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[WHNS]]|publisher=[[Meredith Corporation]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=SCDOT considering partial reopen of I-95|url=http://www.foxcarolina.com/story/30182402/scdot-70-miles-of-i-95-closed-due-to-flooding|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref> On October 16, the following counties were added to the list of federal disaster areas: [[Abbeville County, South Carolina|Abbeville]], [[Anderson County, South Carolina|Anderson]], [[Bamberg County, South Carolina|Bamberg]], [[Colleton County, South Carolina|Colleton]], [[Darlington County, South Carolina|Darlington]], [[Fairfield County, South Carolina|Fairfield]], [[Florence County, South Carolina|Florence]], [[Laurens County, South Carolina|Laurens]], [[McCormick County, South Carolina|McCormick]], and [[Newberry County, South Carolina|Newberry]] counties.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abccolumbia.com/news/local/333316241.html|title=FEMA approves 11 more SC counties for public assistance|work=[[WOLO]]|publisher=[[Bahakel Communications]]|date=October 16, 2015|accessdate=October 16, 2015|location=Columbia, South Carolina}}</ref>
[[Looting]] was reported in some areas of Columbia that had been evacuated.<ref name="CNN3">{{cite news|author1=Holly Yan |author2=Ray Sanchez |lastauthoramp=yes |work=[[CNN]]|publisher=[[Turner Broadcasting System]]|date=October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015|title=South Carolina flooding: dams breached, more trouble ahead|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/06/us/south-carolina-flooding/}}</ref>
On October 5, 541 roads were closed.<ref name=Weaver/>
It was announced October 9, that 18 bridges along 13 miles of Interstate 95 had foundation damage that still needed repairs, which would start October 10. Until the repairs were done, drivers had to make a detour of 94 extra miles by Columbia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://counton2.com/2015/10/09/sc-flooding-repairs-to-begin-soon-on-i-95-after-floods/|title=SC Flooding: Repairs to begin soon on I-95 after floods|work=[[WCBD-TV]]|agency=Associated Press|date=October 9, 2015|accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> Southbound lanes on the final 16 miles of Interstate 95 opened October 12<ref>{{cite news|url=http://counton2.com/ap/interstate-95-reopening-in-south-carolina-as-flooding-ebbs/|title=Interstate 95 reopening in South Carolina as flooding ebbs|last=Smith|first=Bruce|work=WCBD-TV|agency=Associated Press|date=October 12, 2015|accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref> and all of the interstate reopened by 8 A.M. EDT on October 13, after structural repairs to 13 bridges.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://counton2.com/2015/10/13/i-95-now-open-in-both-directions-over-4000-man-hours-worked-to-complete-repairs/|title=Road Updates: I-95 now open in both directions; over 4,000 hours worked|last=Bazzle|first=Kelly|work=WCBD-TV|date=October 23, 2015|accessdate=November 19, 2015}}</ref>
By November 25, 2015, 69 roads were closed. 26 of those needed repair or replacement of private dams to take place. A [[South Carolina Department of Transportation]] report said 221 bridges were affected and 18 would have to be replaced. Workers removed 2000 truckloads of debris from roads.<ref name=Weaver>{{cite news|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/news/local/article47265710.html|title=Milder hurricane season comes to an end, South Carolina still recovering from flood|last=Weaver|first=Emily|work=[[The Sun News]]|date=November 30, 2015|accessdate=December 1, 2015}}</ref> The estimated cost of road repairs was $137 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/news/local/article49510905.html|title=South Carolina set to replace ruined bridges|last=Cope|first=Cassie|work=[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]|date=December 12, 2015|accessdate=December 17, 2015}}</ref>
As of August 2017, almost 2 years to the date, there are still several roads and private dams that are in disrepair.

'''Old field''' is a term used in ecology to describe lands formerly cultivated or grazed but later abandoned. The dominant flora include perennial [[grasses]], [[Ericaceae|heath]]s and [[herbaceous]] plants. Old fields are canonically defined as an intermediate stage found in [[ecological succession]] in an ecosystem advancing towards its [[climax community]], a concept which has been debated by contemporary ecologists for some time.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233623491_Implications_of_Modern_Successional_Theory_for_Habitat_Typing_A_Review|title=Implications of Modern Successional Theory for Habitat Typing: A Review (PDF Download Available)|website=ResearchGate|language=en|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref>
Old field sites are often marginal lands with soil quality unsuitable for crops or pasture. Examples include abandoned farmlands in central [[Ontario]], along the edge of the [[Canadian Shield]].
Stress tolerant species with wide seed dispersal ranges are able to colonize cultivated fields after their initial abandonment, usually followed by perennial grasses.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kelemen|first=András|last2=Tóthmérész|first2=Béla|last3=Valkó|first3=Orsolya|last4=Miglécz|first4=Tamás|last5=Deák|first5=Balázs|last6=Török|first6=Péter|date=2017-04-01|title=New aspects of grassland recovery in old-fields revealed by trait-based analyses of perennial-crop-mediated succession|journal=Ecology and Evolution|volume=7|issue=7|pages=2432–2440|doi=10.1002/ece3.2869|pmc=5383495|pmid=28405306}}</ref> The succession of old fields culminates in takeover by trees and shrubs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gill|first=David S.|last2=Marks|first2=P. L.|date=1991-01-01|title=Tree and Shrub Seedling Colonization of Old Fields in Central New York|jstor=1943007|journal=Ecological Monographs|volume=61|issue=2|pages=183–205|doi=10.2307/1943007}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Brownfield land]]: abandoned or underused industrial and commercial facilities *[[Greenfield land]]: undeveloped land in a city or rural area *[[Indian old field]]: land formerly occupied or used by [[Native Americans in the United States]] *[[Urban prairie]]: vacant urban land that has reverted to green space

{{See also|Painting and the environment}}
Paint is a recyclable item. Latex paint is collected at collection facilities in many countries and shipped to paint-recycling facilities.
== How paint is recycled == There are many ways that [[paint]] can be [[recycling|recycled]]. Most often, the highest quality of latex paint is sorted out and turned back into recycled paint that can be used. Recycled paint is environmentally preferable to new paint, while still maintaining comparable quality. In many cases, reusable paints of the same color are pumped into a tank where the material is mixed and tested. The paint is adjusted with additives and colorants as necessary. Finally, the paint is fine filtered and packaged for sale.
Paint that cannot be reused has other environmentally friendly uses. Non-reusable paint can be made into a product used in cement manufacturing, thereby recycling virtually 100% of the original paint.
Recycling one [[gallon]] of paint could save 13 gallons of [[water]], 1 quart of [[oil]], and 250,000 gallons of [[water pollution]], 13.74 pounds of {{co2}}, save enough energy to power the average home for 3 hours, or cook 6 meals in a microwave oven, or blow dry someone's hair 27 times.
== Paint Product Stewardship Initiative == {{See also|Product stewardship}}
==Paint recycling by country== {{Expand section|date=June 2009}} {{globalize/US|date=December 2010}}
===Canada===
In Ontario, [https://archive.is/20150406084832/http://www.stewardshipontario.ca/case-study/loop-recycled-paint/ Stewardship Ontario] oversees the collection of waste paint from consumers and diversion from landfill to meet targets approved by the Ministry of the Environment through a program called the Orange Drop Program. The Orange Drop program is an extensive and growing network of collection sites—drop-off locations for paint leftovers and other special materials that can’t go in the Blue Box or the garbage.
As an Orange Drop-approved transporter and processor, [http://www.looppaint.com Loop Recycled Products Inc.] [http://looppaint.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/loop_photo_butter-3-267x300.jpg] takes leftover paint, collected through Stewardship Ontario, and turns it into 12 shades of premium, affordable and environmentally friendly recycled paint. Reusing top-quality residual paint (on average, the original retail value of a gallon of incoming paint is approximately $30) enables Loop to create premium products without the raw material costs and energy consumption needed to make paint from scratch.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stewardshipontario.ca/case-study/loop-recycled-paint/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150406084832/http://www.stewardshipontario.ca/case-study/loop-recycled-paint/ |archivedate=2015-04-06 |df= }}</ref>
Since 2012, [http://www.looppaint.com Loop Recycled Products Inc.] has diverted over 6 million litres of paint from disposal in Ontario’s landfills, incineration and waterways and is committed to innovation and solving Canada’s waste paint problem.
In February 2015 [http://wdo.ca/ Waste Diversion Ontario] approved Product Care as the new Ontario waste paint stewardship operator effectively replacing Stewardship Ontario.
In March 2017, [http://www.colortech.info Colortech ECO Paints] introduced its line of recycled wall and floor paints to specific retail markets consisting of a large network of liquidation and discount stores across Canada and the United States., as well as exporting large quantities to West Africa and South America.
Alberta’s paint recycling program started accepting leftover, unwanted paint on April 1, 2008. It is estimated that about 30 million liters of paint is sold in Alberta each year. On average, 5 to 10 percent of this ends up as waste, which can pose environmental and health risks if disposed of improperly. Paint contains many components that have great potential for reuse, recycling and recovery. The Paint Recycling Alberta program enables these products to be handled and recycled in an environmentally safe manner, reducing their impact on the environment. The program is funded through environmental fees charged on the sale of new paint in Alberta. The fees are put into a dedicated fund that can only be used to manage the paint recycling program.
The paint is sorted into different streams and sent to registered processors to be recycled into new paint, used in other products or in energy recovery, or sent for proper disposal if necessary. Any processor that receives paint must be registered with the Paint Recycling Program and meet all applicable environmental, transportation, health & safety, and local requirements.
[http://www.recyclepaint.com Calibre Environmental LTD.] (CEL) located in Calgary, Alberta, became a key part in 2008 of the new Alberta Paint Stewardship program which significantly increased the recycling of unused latex paint from across the province of Alberta. Calibre Environmental Ltd. currently processes about 1.6 million kilograms of latex paint annually, which equates to the successful recycling of one million litres of quality latex paint per year.
===New Zealand=== {{Empty section|date=January 2011}}
===United Kingdom=== In the UK reusable leftover paint can be donated to [http://www.communityrepaint.org.uk Community RePaint], a national network of paint reuse schemes. The network comprises local schemes run by not-for-profit organisations, local authorities or waste management companies, in the Community RePaint network. The schemes collect surplus paint from trade sources i.e. painters, decorators, retailers, manufacturers, and/or leftover paint donated by householders at council household waste and recycling centres (also known as tips). The paint is then sorted by staff and volunteers before being redistributed to local charities, community groups, families and individuals in need. The Community RePaint network, is sponsored by [[Dulux]] (part of [[AkzoNobel]]), managed by an environmental consultancy, [http://www.resourcefutures.co.uk Resource Futures] and has been cited as an example of best practice for the management of surplus paint in a report by the European Commission<ref>{{cite web|last=European|first=Commission|title=Study on Hazardous Household Waste with a main emphasis on Hazardous Household Chemicals|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/waste/studies/pdf/household_report.pdf|publisher=European Commission Directorate - General Environment|accessdate=2011-11-23|author2=Gendebien, A. |author3=Leavens, A. |author4=Blackmore, K. |author5=Godley, A. |author6=Lewin, K. |author7=Franke, B. |author8=Franke, A. |date=July 2002}}</ref> and by [[DEFRA]] in Guidance on Applying the [[Waste hierarchy|Waste Hierarchy]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Defra|title=Guidance on Applying the Waste Hierarchy|url=http://www.defra.gov.uk/publications/files/pb13530-waste-hierarchy-guidance.pdf|publisher=Defra|accessdate=2011-11-23|date=June 2011}}</ref>
There are also a handful of companies recycling paint in the UK, but only two reprocessing waste paint, back into the quality of virgin paint; [http://www.newlifepaints.com/ Newlife Paints]. Newlife Paints was formed in 2008 after [http://www.newlifepaints.com/about Keith Harrison], an industrial chemist, developed a process that converted waste emulsion paint back into full quality, commercial grade paint.<ref>{{cite web|last=New Life Paints|title=About Us|url=http://www.newlifepaints.com/about.html|accessdate=2011-11-23}}</ref> Castle RePaint, part of the social enterprise company Castle Furniture also consolidates unwanted emulsion paint into brand new 'RePaint' in a range of colours.
===United States===
Concerns about the life cycle of paint have led to the creation of [http://www.paintcare.org/ PaintCare], a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization established to represent paint manufacturers (paint producers) to plan and operate paint stewardship programs in the United States in those states that pass paint stewardship laws.<ref name="paintcare.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.paintcare.org/about/|title=About PaintCare|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2017}}</ref>
Paint stewardship law aims to enable the paint industry to implement a collection program that allows consumers to take their leftover, unwanted paint to a collection site to be collected and recycled. Legislation mandating the creation of the PaintCare program has been enacted in eight states since 2009: Oregon, California, Connecticut, Rhode Island, Vermont, Minnesota, Maine, and Colorado. Legislation has also been passed for the District of Columbia; PaintCare anticipates beginning the District's paint stewardship program in September 2016. PaintCare is responsible for promoting the reuse of post-consumer [[architectural paint]] (leftover paint) and providing for the collection, transport, and processing of this paint using the hierarchy of "reduce, reuse, recycle," and proper disposal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paint.org/publications-resources/issue-backgrounder/aca-paintcare/|title=ACA & PaintCare - American Coatings Association|publisher=|accessdate=24 November 2017}}</ref> Most PaintCare locations are at paint retailers who volunteer to take back paint. These retailers take back paint during regular business hours, making paint recycling and disposal much more convenient for the public.<ref name="paintcare.org"/>
Paint is shipped to companies such as [[Amazon Environmental]], [[American Paint Recyclers]] (Ohio), GDB International, Metro Paint (Oregon), UCI Environmental (Nevada) and Kelly Moore, Visions Paint Recycling, Inc (California)& Williams Paint Recycling Company. In the Southern California area, Acrylatex Coatings & Recycling, Inc. accepts unused/unwanted latex paints for reprocessing into a viable resource of recycled paints in 20-standard colors. In the southeastern United States Atlanta Paint Disposal has a paint recycling program with drop off locations in Atlanta, Georgia. In the northeast The Paint Exchange, LLC recycles latex paint under the brand recolor®.
A new charitable organization known as [[The Global Paint for Charity]] incorporated in Georgia, US, has as its mission to collect leftover paint from residents and businesses nationwide and use it for global housing rehabilitation projects, including homes, schools, hospitals, jails and churches for vulnerable families in developing countries. They partner with non-profit organizations with existing operations in these continents for paint distribution. Through the support of their donors and partners they are able to improve communities, increase access to quality paints and protect the environment.
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) estimates that every homeowner in the US has 3 to 4 gallons of leftover paints in their basement, and 10 percent of those paints ends up in landfills.
One gallon of improperly disposed paint has the ability to pollute up to 250,000 gallons of water.
By participating in the program, individuals and businesses will take greater steps to protect the environment, and improve living conditions for vulnerable populations throughout the world. If you would like to support the Global Paint for Charity, they encourage you to take action today.
Improve access of high-quality paints to vulnerable populations around the world. Nearly 2.5 billion people in developing countries live on less than $2 a day. For them, paint is very expensive. In these settings, it is very difficult for families to secure sufficient income for their basic needs (including but not limited to: food, medicine, water, clothes, school supplies, and shelter). When making consumption choices that involve spending on their basic needs there is nothing left to spend on paint. The paint shortage affects many other areas of the world, where communities lack even the most basic need and materials to uplift their people. For the world’s poorest communities, home isn’t just where the heart is. Dirt walls and neglected communities are not attractive to tourists, putting those who cannot afford paint, not only at the greatest risk of life-threatening of bad germs but also lack of economic opportunities.
Since it started years ago, as many as 500–6000 gallons of paint have been shipped at a time to developing countries, including Kenya, Uganda, Haiti, Dominican Republic, Honduras, El Salvador, Guyana, Guinea, Ghana, Jamaica and Mexico, 240 volunteers have painted 459 family homes and 40 schools and orphanages with over 150,000 gallons of donated paint from businesses and residences.
Global Paint for Charity continues to expand and impact our communities around the world. They do this through working directly with their volunteers, donors, and partners. From developing paint projects that engage their employees in the beautification of the community; to run frequent local paint drives to support their program.
Global Paint for Charity has recently won the National Energy Globe Award of United States 2017. With more than 178 participating countries and over 2,000 project submissions annually the Energy Globe Award is today's most prestigious environmental prize worldwide. The Austrian Honorary Consul General, Mr. Ferdinand C. Seefried hosted an exclusive ceremony to present the National Energy Globe Award 2017 for the United States to Mr. Rony Delgarde, Global Paint for Charity.
